reasoning:
The critique targets the essay’s brief “memetic hazard / epistemic black hole” blocker and alleges an asymmetric application: if memetic fitness can diverge from truth, the essay’s own pessimistic arguments might also be memetically selected. That point is somewhat relevant but not very central to the essay’s main thrust (which is largely about (non-)convergence under realism/antirealism, motivation, and the prospects for compromise/trade plus threats). Even if the memetics-blocker were removed or the asymmetry charge stuck, most of the argument would remain.

As an objection to the memetics-blocker, it has moderate force: it correctly identifies a symmetry/self-undermining risk and a need for some epistemic story about why we should trust the essay’s reasoning despite acknowledging memetic selection. However, it doesn’t strongly refute the essay’s overall pessimism because (i) the essay does not lean heavily on the memetics point, and (ii) one can consistently hold “memetic selection is a risk” while also thinking some arguments are robust (e.g., via methodological safeguards, independent checks, or domain-specific reasons), none of which the critique shows are unavailable.

The critique is clear and focused with little extraneous material, but it makes a speculative empirical claim about why the essay is compelling (“pessimism is memetically fit in academic contexts”), which is plausible but not established—so correctness is good but not perfect.
title: Memetic selection pressures apply equally to the paper's own pessimistic conclusions
